what: How do we make signature objects?
title: Adding Sig Objects to TBSP
text: ’s easy! Just make named list genes. LOT genes? Theoretically, genes well automate process!
code: Sweeney_OD_3 <- c("KLF2", "GBP5", "DUSP3") Blankley_5 <- c("AIM2", "BATF2", "FCGR1B", "HP", "TLR5")  example_TB <- list("Sweeney_OD_3" = Sweeney_OD_3,      "Blankley_5" = Blankley_5)  str(example_TB) ## List of 2 ##  $ Sweeney_OD_3: chr [1:3] "KLF2" "GBP5" "DUSP3" ##  $ Blankley_5  : chr [1:5] "AIM2" "BATF2" "FCGR1B" "HP" ... # Make a temporary CSV TBsignatures$Blankley_380 %>%   TBSignatureProfiler::update_genenames() %>%   tibble(Blankley_380 = .) %>%   write_csv(file = "~/temp_380_genes.csv")  # Read the CSV Blankley_380 <- read_csv("~/temp_380_genes.csv") ## Rows: 383 Columns: 1 ## ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── ## Delimiter: "," ## chr (1): Blankley_380 ##  ## ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. ## ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message. Blankley_380[1:5, ] ## # A tibble: 5 × 1 ##   Blankley_380 ##   <chr>        ## 1 AIM2         ## 2 BATF2        ## 3 FCGR1B       ## 4 HP           ## 5 TLR5 # Add to list new_example_TB <- example_TB new_example_TB$Blankley_380 <- Blankley_380$Blankley_380  str(new_example_TB) ## List of 3 ##  $ Sweeney_OD_3: chr [1:3] "KLF2" "GBP5" "DUSP3" ##  $ Blankley_5  : chr [1:5] "AIM2" "BATF2" "FCGR1B" "HP" ... ##  $ Blankley_380: chr [1:383] "AIM2" "BATF2" "FCGR1B" "HP" ... add_genes <- function(input_list, new_sig_name, sig_path) {   new_sig_genes <- read_csv(sig_path, show_col_types = FALSE)   input_list[new_sig_name] <- new_sig_genes[, 1]   return(input_list) }  str(example_TB) ## List of 2 ##  $ Sweeney_OD_3: chr [1:3] "KLF2" "GBP5" "DUSP3" ##  $ Blankley_5  : chr [1:5] "AIM2" "BATF2" "FCGR1B" "HP" ... automated_ex_tb <- add_genes(example_TB, "Blankley_380", "~/temp_380_genes.csv")  str(automated_ex_tb) ## List of 3 ##  $ Sweeney_OD_3: chr [1:3] "KLF2" "GBP5" "DUSP3" ##  $ Blankley_5  : chr [1:5] "AIM2" "BATF2" "FCGR1B" "HP" ... ##  $ Blankley_380: chr [1:383] "AIM2" "BATF2" "FCGR1B" "HP" ...

code: # make sure this is in the same order as the signatures object   # Best to alphebetize using sort() (and change rows using order()) head(sigAnnotData) ##            names disease tissue_type ## 1    Anderson_42 Disease       whole ## 2 Anderson_OD_51      OD       whole ## 3      Berry_393 Disease       whole ## 4    Berry_OD_86      OD       whole ## 5   Blankley_380 Disease       mixed ## 6     Blankley_5 Disease       mixed data("TB_hiv")  sigs_to_run <- TBsignatures[20:40] out <- capture.output(res <- runTBsigProfiler(TB_hiv, useAssay = "counts",                         signatures = sigs_to_run,                         algorithm = c("ssGSEA"), parallel.sz = 1,                         combineSigAndAlgorithm = TRUE)) ## Parameter update_genes is TRUE. Gene names will be updated. ## Running ssGSEA ## Warning in .filterFeatures(expr, method): 2204 genes with constant expression ## values throuhgout the samples. signatureHeatmap(res, signatureColNames = names(sigs_to_run),                  annotationColNames = "Disease", scale = TRUE,                  showColumnNames = FALSE, split_heatmap = "tissue_type")

title: Introduction to the TBSignatureProfiler
text: Tuberculosis (TB) leading cause infectious disease mortality worldwide, causing average nearly 1.4 million deaths per year. consistent issue faced controlling TB outbreak difficulty diagnosing individuals particular types TB infections bacteria tests (e.g., via GeneXpert, sputum) prove inaccurate. alternative mechanism diagnosis infections, researchers discovered published multiple gene expression signatures blood-based disease biomarkers. context, gene signatures defined combined group genes uniquely characteristic pattern gene expression occurs result medical condition. date, 75 signatures published researchers, though relatively low cross-condition validation (e.g., testing TB samples diverse geographic comorbidity backgrounds). Furthermore, signatures never formally collected made available single unified resource. aim provide scientific community resource access aggregated signatures create efficient means visual quantitative comparison via open source software. necessitated development TBSignatureProfiler, novel R package delivers computational profiling platform researchers characterize diagnostic ability existing signatures multiple comorbidity settings. software allows signature strength estimation via several enrichment methods subsequent visualization single- multi-pathway results. signature evaluation functionalities include signature profiling, AUC bootstrapping, leave-one-cross-validation (LOOCV) logistic regression approximate TB samples’ status. plotting functionalities include sample-signature score heatmaps, bootstrap AUC LOOCV boxplots, tables presenting results. recently, TBSignatureProfiler undertaken new role analyzing signatures across multiple chronic airway diseases, recent COVID-19 (see COVIDsignatures object). grow expand TBSignatureProfiler, hope add signatures multiple diseases improve package’s utility area gene signature comparison.

title: Introduction to the TBSignatureProfiler

code: if (!requireNamespace("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))   install.packages("BiocManager") BiocManager::install("TBSignatureProfiler")

title: Introduction to the TBSignatureProfiler
text: tutorial, work HIV Tuberculosis (TB) gene expression data SummarizedExperiment format. dataset included TBSignatureProfiler package can loaded global environment data("TB_hiv"). 31 samples dataset marked either TB HIV infection, HIV infection . begin examining dataset, contains matrix counts information (“assay” SummarizedExperiment terms) another matrix meta data information samples (“colData”). also generate additional assays; log(counts), counts per million (CPM) reads mapped, log(CPM) assays. now make log counts, CPM log CPM assay.
code: ## HIV/TB gene expression data, included in the package hivtb_data <- TB_hiv  ### Note that we have 25,369 genes, 33 samples, and 1 assay of counts dim(hivtb_data) ## [1] 25369    31 # We start with only one assay assays(hivtb_data) ## List of length 1 ## names(1): counts ## Make a log counts, CPM and log CPM assay hivtb_data <- mkAssay(hivtb_data, log = TRUE, counts_to_CPM = TRUE)  ### Check to see that we now have 4 assays assays(hivtb_data) ## List of length 4 ## names(4): counts log_counts counts_cpm log_counts_cpm

title: Introduction to the TBSignatureProfiler
text: TBSignatureProfiler enables comparison multiple Tuberculosis gene signatures. package currently contains information 79 signatures comparison. default signature list object functions TBsignatures, although list publication-given signature names also available TBcommon object. Data frames annotation information signatures, including information associated disease tissue type, can accessed sigAnnotData common_sigAnnotData respectively. runTBSigProfiler function, able score signatures selection algorithms, including gene set variation analysis (GSVA) (Hänzelmann et al, 2013), single-sample GSEA (ssGSEA) (Barbie et al, 2009), ASSIGN pathway profiling toolkit (Shen et al, 2015). complete list included scoring methods, run ?runTBsigProfiler terminal. , evaluate signatures included package ssGSEA. Paraphrasing ssGSEA documentation, pairing one 31 samples gene set, ssGSEA calculates separate enrichment score independent phenotypic labeling (case, whether sample HIV/TB, HIV ). single sample’s gene expression profile transformed gene set enrichment profile. score set profile represents activity level biological process gene set’s members coordinately - -regulated. SummarizedExperiment format input data runTBsigprofiler, returned object also SummarizedExperiment. scores returned part colData. , subset data compare enrichment scores Anderson_42, Anderson_OD_51, Zak_RISK_16 signatures. Signature Scores
code: ## List all signatures in the profiler data("TBsignatures") names(TBsignatures) ##  [1] "Anderson_42"       "Anderson_OD_51"    "Berry_393"         ##  [4] "Berry_OD_86"       "Blankley_380"      "Blankley_5"        ##  [7] "Bloom_OD_144"      "Bloom_RES_268"     "Bloom_RES_558"     ## [10] "Chen_5"            "Chen_HIV_4"        "Chendi_HIV_2"      ## [13] "Darboe_RISK_11"    "Dawany_HIV_251"    "Duffy_23"          ## [16] "Esmail_203"        "Esmail_82"         "Esmail_OD_893"     ## [19] "Estevez_133"       "Estevez_259"       "Francisco_OD_2"    ## [22] "Gjoen_10"          "Gjoen_7"           "Gliddon_2_OD_4"    ## [25] "Gliddon_HIV_3"     "Gliddon_OD_3"      "Gliddon_OD_4"      ## [28] "Gong_OD_4"         "Heycken_FAIL_22"   "Hoang_OD_13"       ## [31] "Hoang_OD_20"       "Hoang_OD_3"        "Huang_OD_13"       ## [34] "Jacobsen_3"        "Jenum_8"           "Kaforou_27"        ## [37] "Kaforou_OD_44"     "Kaforou_OD_53"     "Kaul_3"            ## [40] "Kulkarni_HIV_2"    "Kwan_186"          "LauxdaCosta_OD_3"  ## [43] "Lee_4"             "Leong_24"          "Leong_RISK_29"     ## [46] "Long_RES_10"       "Maertzdorf_15"     "Maertzdorf_4"      ## [49] "Maertzdorf_OD_100" "Natarajan_7"       "PennNich_RISK_6"   ## [52] "Qian_OD_17"        "Rajan_HIV_5"       "Roe_3"             ## [55] "Roe_OD_4"          "Sambarey_HIV_10"   "Singhania_OD_20"   ## [58] "Sivakumaran_11"    "Sloot_HIV_2"       "Suliman_4"         ## [61] "Suliman_RISK_2"    "Suliman_RISK_4"    "Sweeney_OD_3"      ## [64] "Tabone_OD_11"      "Tabone_RES_25"     "Tabone_RES_27"     ## [67] "Thompson_9"        "Thompson_FAIL_13"  "Thompson_RES_5"    ## [70] "Tornheim_71"       "Tornheim_RES_25"   "Vargas_18"         ## [73] "Vargas_42"         "Verhagen_10"       "Walter_51"         ## [76] "Walter_PNA_119"    "Walter_PNA_47"     "Zak_RISK_16"       ## [79] "Zhao_NANO_6" ## We can use all of these signatures for further analysis siglist_hivtb <- names(TBsignatures) ## Run the TBSignatureProfiler to score the signatures in the data out <- capture.output(ssgsea_result <- runTBsigProfiler(input = hivtb_data,                                                  useAssay = "log_counts_cpm",                                                  signatures = TBsignatures,                                                  algorithm = "ssGSEA",                                                  combineSigAndAlgorithm = TRUE,                                                  parallel.sz = 1)) ## Parameter update_genes is TRUE. Gene names will be updated. ## The following signatures have <2 genes that coincide with the genes in the given sample and will not be scored: Chendi_HIV_2 ## Running ssGSEA ## Warning: no function found corresponding to methods exports from 'HDF5Array' ## for: 'extract_sparse_array' ## Warning: multiple methods tables found for 'sparsity' ## Warning in .filterGenes(dataMatrix, dropConstantRows = FALSE): 2204 rows with ## constant values throughout the samples. ## Remove any signatures that were not scored TBsignatures <- subset(TBsignatures, !(names(TBsignatures) %in% c("Chendi_HIV_2"))) ## New colData entries from the Profiler sigs <- c("Anderson_42", "Anderson_OD_51", "Zak_RISK_16") ssgsea_print_results <- as.data.frame(colData(ssgsea_result))[, c("Disease", sigs)] ssgsea_print_results[, 2:4] <- round(ssgsea_print_results[, 2:4], 4)  DT::datatable(ssgsea_print_results)

text: Another method signature evaluation featured TBSignatureProfiler package available SignatureQuantitative function. training process, bootstrap samples, cross-validate logistic regression prediction TB HIV status sample, calculate validation set AUCs cross-validation iteration. theory, signature useful predictor status, higher average AUC logistic regression bootstraps. also create boxplot AUC signature, provides clear comparison signatures.
code: ### Make an additional binary indicator for signature evaluation hivtb_data$BinaryTB <- as.numeric(hivtb_data$Disease) - 1  ## We can normalize the data and evaluate the signatures hivtb_norm <- deseq2_norm_rle(assay(hivtb_data, "counts"))  quantitative.result <- SignatureQuantitative(hivtb_norm,                        targetVec.num = colData(hivtb_data)$BinaryTB,                        signature.list = TBsignatures[sigs],                        signature.name.vec = sigs,                        num.boot = 3,                        pb.show = FALSE) plotQuantitative(hivtb_norm, targetVec.num = colData(hivtb_data)$BinaryTB,                        signature.list = TBsignatures[sigs],                        signature.name.vec = sigs,                        num.boot = 3, pb.show = FALSE, rotateLabels = TRUE)

title: Introduction to the TBSignatureProfiler
text: Tuberculosis (TB) leading cause infectious disease mortality worldwide, causing average nearly 1.4 million deaths per year. consistent issue faced controlling TB outbreak difficulty diagnosing individuals particular types TB infections bacteria tests (e.g., via GeneXpert, sputum) prove inaccurate. alternative mechanism diagnosis infections, researchers discovered published multiple gene expression signatures blood-based disease biomarkers. context, gene signatures defined combined group genes uniquely characteristic pattern gene expression occurs result medical condition. date, 75 signatures published researchers, though relatively low cross-condition validation (e.g., testing TB samples diverse geographic comorbidity backgrounds). Furthermore, signatures never formally collected made available single unified resource. aim provide scientific community resource access aggregated signatures create efficient means visual quantitative comparison via open source software. necessitated development TBSignatureProfiler, novel R package delivers computational profiling platform researchers characterize diagnostic ability existing signatures multiple comorbidity settings. software allows signature strength estimation via several enrichment methods subsequent visualization single- multi-pathway results. signature evaluation functionalities include signature profiling, AUC bootstrapping, leave-one-cross-validation (LOOCV) logistic regression approximate TB samples’ status. plotting functionalities include sample-signature score heatmaps, bootstrap AUC LOOCV boxplots, tables presenting results. recently, TBSignatureProfiler undertaken new role analyzing signatures across multiple chronic airway diseases, recent COVID-19 (see COVIDsignatures object). grow expand TBSignatureProfiler, hope add signatures multiple diseases improve package’s utility area gene signature comparison.

title: Introduction to the TBSignatureProfiler
text: tutorial, work HIV Tuberculosis (TB) gene expression data SummarizedExperiment format. dataset included TBSignatureProfiler package can loaded global environment data("TB_hiv"). 31 samples dataset marked either TB HIV infection, HIV infection . begin examining dataset, contains matrix counts information (“assay” SummarizedExperiment terms) another matrix meta data information samples (“colData”). also generate additional assays; log(counts), counts per million (CPM) reads mapped, log(CPM) assays. now make log counts, CPM log CPM assay.
code: ## HIV/TB gene expression data, included in the package hivtb_data <- TB_hiv  ### Note that we have 25,369 genes, 33 samples, and 1 assay of counts dim(hivtb_data) ## [1] 25369    31 # We start with only one assay assays(hivtb_data) ## List of length 1 ## names(1): counts ## Make a log counts, CPM and log CPM assay hivtb_data <- mkAssay(hivtb_data, log = TRUE, counts_to_CPM = TRUE)  ### Check to see that we now have 4 assays assays(hivtb_data) ## List of length 4 ## names(4): counts log_counts counts_cpm log_counts_cpm

title: Introduction to the TBSignatureProfiler
text: TBSignatureProfiler enables comparison multiple Tuberculosis gene signatures. package currently contains information 79 signatures comparison. default signature list object functions TBsignatures, although list publication-given signature names also available TBcommon. Data frames annotation information signatures, including information associated disease tissue type, can accessed sigAnnotData common_sigAnnotData respectively. runTBSigProfiler function, able score signatures selection algorithms, including gene set variation analysis (GSVA) (Hänzelmann et al, 2013), single-sample GSEA (ssGSEA) (Barbie et al, 2009), ASSIGN pathway profiling toolkit (Shen et al, 2015). complete list included scoring methods, run ?runTBsigProfiler terminal. , evaluate signatures included package ssGSEA. Paraphrasing ssGSEA documentation, pairing one 31 samples gene set, ssGSEA calculates separate enrichment score independent phenotypic labeling (case, whether sample HIV/TB, HIV ). single sample’s gene expression profile transformed gene set enrichment profile. score set profile represents activity level biological process gene set’s members coordinately - -regulated. SummarizedExperiment format input data runTBsigprofiler, returned object also SummarizedExperiment. scores returned part colData. , subset data compare enrichment scores Anderson_42, Anderson_OD_51, Zak_RISK_16 signatures. Signature Scores
code: ## List all signatures in the profiler data("TBsignatures") names(TBsignatures) ##  [1] "Anderson_42"       "Anderson_OD_51"    "Berry_393"         ##  [4] "Berry_OD_86"       "Blankley_380"      "Blankley_5"        ##  [7] "Bloom_OD_144"      "Bloom_RES_268"     "Bloom_RES_558"     ## [10] "Chen_5"            "Chen_HIV_4"        "Chendi_HIV_2"      ## [13] "Darboe_RISK_11"    "Dawany_HIV_251"    "Duffy_23"          ## [16] "Esmail_203"        "Esmail_82"         "Esmail_OD_893"     ## [19] "Estevez_133"       "Estevez_259"       "Francisco_OD_2"    ## [22] "Gjoen_10"          "Gjoen_7"           "Gliddon_2_OD_4"    ## [25] "Gliddon_HIV_3"     "Gliddon_OD_3"      "Gliddon_OD_4"      ## [28] "Gong_OD_4"         "Heycken_FAIL_22"   "Hoang_OD_13"       ## [31] "Hoang_OD_20"       "Hoang_OD_3"        "Huang_OD_13"       ## [34] "Jacobsen_3"        "Jenum_8"           "Kaforou_27"        ## [37] "Kaforou_OD_44"     "Kaforou_OD_53"     "Kaul_3"            ## [40] "Kulkarni_HIV_2"    "Kwan_186"          "LauxdaCosta_OD_3"  ## [43] "Lee_4"             "Leong_24"          "Leong_RISK_29"     ## [46] "Long_RES_10"       "Maertzdorf_15"     "Maertzdorf_4"      ## [49] "Maertzdorf_OD_100" "Natarajan_7"       "PennNich_RISK_6"   ## [52] "Qian_OD_17"        "Rajan_HIV_5"       "Roe_3"             ## [55] "Roe_OD_4"          "Sambarey_HIV_10"   "Singhania_OD_20"   ## [58] "Sivakumaran_11"    "Sloot_HIV_2"       "Suliman_4"         ## [61] "Suliman_RISK_2"    "Suliman_RISK_4"    "Sweeney_OD_3"      ## [64] "Tabone_OD_11"      "Tabone_RES_25"     "Tabone_RES_27"     ## [67] "Thompson_9"        "Thompson_FAIL_13"  "Thompson_RES_5"    ## [70] "Tornheim_71"       "Tornheim_RES_25"   "Vargas_18"         ## [73] "Vargas_42"         "Verhagen_10"       "Walter_51"         ## [76] "Walter_PNA_119"    "Walter_PNA_47"     "Zak_RISK_16"       ## [79] "Zhao_NANO_6" ## We can use all of these signatures for further analysis siglist_hivtb <- names(TBsignatures) ## Run the TBSignatureProfiler to score the signatures in the data out <- capture.output(ssgsea_result <- runTBsigProfiler(input = hivtb_data,                                                  useAssay = "log_counts_cpm",                                                  signatures = TBsignatures,                                                  algorithm = "ssGSEA",                                                  combineSigAndAlgorithm = TRUE,                                                  parallel.sz = 1)) ## Parameter update_genes is TRUE. Gene names will be updated. ## The following signatures have <2 genes that coincide with the genes in the given sample and will not be scored: Chendi_HIV_2 ## Running ssGSEA ## Warning: no function found corresponding to methods exports from 'HDF5Array' ## for: 'extract_sparse_array' ## Warning: multiple methods tables found for 'sparsity' ## Warning in .filterGenes(dataMatrix, dropConstantRows = FALSE): 2204 rows with ## constant values throughout the samples. ## Remove any signatures that were not scored TBsignatures <- subset(TBsignatures, !(names(TBsignatures) %in% c("Chendi_HIV_2"))) ## New colData entries from the Profiler sigs <- c("Anderson_42", "Anderson_OD_51", "Zak_RISK_16") ssgsea_print_results <- as.data.frame(   colData(ssgsea_result))[, c("Disease", sigs)] ssgsea_print_results[, 2:4] <- round(ssgsea_print_results[, 2:4], 4)  DT::datatable(ssgsea_print_results)

title: Profile RNA-Seq Data Using TB Pathway Signatures
text: TBSignatureProfiler (TBSP) easy--use R package analysis RNA-seq data using gene signatures tuberculosis disease presence, risk, progression, treatment failure, states. -package signature profiling available using common gene set enrichment tools include GSVA, singscore, ssGSEA. Users can analyze RNA-seq data across 70+ published gene signatures compare signature performance clear visualizations (e.g., heatmaps ROC plots), specificity/sensitivity estimates predicting binary variables, cross-validated logistic regression. TBSP can used standalone software package. Data exploration also available accompanying interactive R Shiny application. R Shiny app currently functional limited capabilities command line form package.

BMC Infect Dis 21, 106 (2021).

title: Use logistic regression and bootstrap LOOCV to evaluate signatures. — SignatureQuantitative
text: df.input data.frame gene expression count data. Required. targetVec.num numeric binary vector response variable. vector number rows df. Required. signature.list list signatures run associated genes. list format TBsignatures, included TBSignatureProfiler package. signature.list = NULL, default set signatures TBsignatures list used. details, run ?TBsignatures. signature.name.vec vector specifying names signatures compared. length signature.list. signature.name.vec = NULL, default set signatures TBsignatures list used. num.boot integer specifying number bootstrap iterations. pb.show logical. TRUE progress bar bootstrapping procedure displayed output. default TRUE. name character string giving name outputted boxplot bootstrapped AUCs. default "Quantitative Evaluation Signatures via Bootstrapped AUCs".

title: Use logistic regression and bootstrap LOOCV to evaluate signatures. — SignatureQuantitative
text: AUC, sensitivity specificity

title: Use logistic regression and bootstrap LOOCV to evaluate signatures. — SignatureQuantitative
code: inputTest <- matrix(rnorm(1000), 100, 20,                     dimnames = list(paste0("gene", seq.int(1, 100)),                                     paste0("sample", seq.int(1, 20)))) inputTest <- as.data.frame(inputTest) targetVec <- sample(c(0,1), replace = TRUE, size = 20) signature.list <- list(sig1 = c("gene1", "gene2", "gene3"),                        sig2 = c("gene4", "gene5", "gene6")) signature.name.vec <- c("sig1", "sig2") num.boot <- 2 SignatureQuantitative(inputTest, targetVec.num = targetVec,                       signature.list = signature.list,                       signature.name.vec = signature.name.vec,                       num.boot = num.boot) #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0%   |                                                                               |===================================                                   |  50%   |                                                                               |======================================================================| 100% #> $df.auc.ci #>      Estimate CI lower.5% CI upper.95%    Std. Error #> sig1   0.4835     0.38054      0.68546 -5.551115e-17 #> sig2   0.4176     0.59555      0.63425  0.000000e+00 #>  #> $df.sensitivity.ci #>      Estimate.Sensitivity CI lower.5% CI upper.95%   Std. Error #> sig1            0.1428571  0.35303030    0.7075758 5.551115e-17 #> sig2            0.2857143  0.03333333    0.6333333 0.000000e+00 #>  #> $df.specificity.ci #>      Estimate.Specificity CI lower.5% CI upper.95%    Std. Error #> sig1            0.7692308   0.1519841    0.8876984 -5.551115e-17 #> sig2            0.7692308   0.7031469    0.8982517  1.110223e-16 #>

Otherwise, signature names composed last name primary author, followed possible context signature, ending either number gene transcripts genes signature respect however described original publication. Possible signature contexts: OD: diseases HIV: Human Immunodeficiency Virus PNA: Pneumonia RISK: Risk developing active TB RES: Response TB treatment FAIL: Failure TB treatment Note cases signatures positive identifiers TB whereas others negative identifiers; taken account creating ROC curves computing AUC estimates.

title: A list of published TB signatures. — TBsignatures
text: Signature names composed last name primary author, followed possible context signature, ending either number gene transcripts genes signature, respect however described signature's original publication. Possible signature contexts: <blank>: TB vs LTBI Healthy Controls OD: diseases HIV: Human Immunodeficiency Virus PNA: Pneumonia RISK: Risk developing active TB RES: Response TB treatment FAIL: Failure TB treatment Note cases signatures positive identifiers TB whereas others negative identifiers; taken account creating ROC curves computing AUC estimates.

what: Introduce a new signature into the TBSignatureProfiler. — addTBsignature
title: Introduce a new signature into the TBSignatureProfiler. — addTBsignature
text: function allows users integrate new signatures TBSP function updates TBsignatures, TBcommon, sigAnnotData common_sigAnnotData objects. Users wish use function downloaded package working directory, casual package function. function complete required updates package signature full added; users check vignette "Submitting Signatures TBSP Package" [TBSP website](https://wejlab.github.io/TBSignatureProfiler-docs/.) walkthrough complete process. Also note function adds one signature time, must run multiple times add subsequent signatures.

title: Introduce a new signature into the TBSignatureProfiler. — addTBsignature
code: addTBsignature(   sigsymbols,   authname,   signame_common = NULL,   sigtype,   tissuetype,   saveobjs = FALSE,   views = TRUE )

title: Introduce a new signature into the TBSignatureProfiler. — addTBsignature
text: sigsymbols character vector gene symbols compose signature added. Required. authname character string containing last name primary author publication signature first identified. spaces present, omit , use proper capitalization. Required. signame_common character string alternate name signature given publication, exists. NULL, assigned name assumed exist. Default null. sigtype character string gives context signature developed . commonly, distinguish TB LTBI ("Disease"), TB combination diseases possibly LTBI ("Disease/Diseases"), TB Human Immunodeficiency Virus ("Disease/HIV"), TB pneumonia ("Disease/Pneumonia"), identify risk progression TB ("risk"), risk TB treatment failure ("failure"), classify treatment responses (.e., failures cures, "response"). Required. tissuetype character string denotes whether signature developed using samples either whole blood/paxgene ("whole blood") peripheral blood mononuclear cells ("PBMC"). Due manipulation cells inherently required obtain PBMCs, many scientists prefer use whole blood samples analysis. Accepts "whole blood", "PBMC" "mixed". Required. saveobjs logical. TRUE, contents data file (TBsignatures, TBcommon, sigAnnotData, common_sigAnnotData) overwritten updated include new signature. FALSE, files overwritten, can check function output errors writing RDS objects setting views = TRUE. Default saveobjs = FALSE. views logical. TRUE, objects sent data view new window check errors. Default TRUE.

title: Introduce a new signature into the TBSignatureProfiler. — addTBsignature
text: Either data objects TBsignatures, TBcommon, sigAnnotData, common_sigAnnotData updated new signature overwritten saveobjs = FALSE, output produced except errors messages checking function runs correctly given inputs.

title: Compare scoring algorithms on a single signature via heatmap or boxplot. — compareAlgs
text: input input data object class "SummarizedExperiment". Required. signatures list signatures run associated genes. list format TBsignatures, included TBSignatureProfiler package. signatures = NULL, default set signatures TBsignatures list used. details, run ?TBsignatures. <2 genes signature present sample, signature evaluated present resulting SE object. default NULL. annotationColName character string giving column name colData contains annotation data. Required. useAssay character string specifying assay use signature profiling input SummarizedExperiment. Required input data class SummarizedExperiment. null, assay used "counts". default NULL. algorithm vector algorithms run, character string one desired. default c("GSVA", "ssGSEA", "ASSIGN", "PLAGE", "Zscore", "singscore"). showColumnNames logical. Setting showColumnNames = TRUE show column names (.e. sample names) heatmap. default TRUE. showRowNames logical. Setting showColumnNames = TRUE show row names (.e. signature names) heatmap. default TRUE. scale logical. Setting scale = TRUE scales signature data. default FALSE. colorSets vector names listing color sets order used creating heatmap. default, function use color sets order listed Usage annotation information. may replace default collection sets order want use , provide custom color sets colList parameter. choose_color vector color names interpolated heatmap gradient, colorRamp function produced circlize::colorRamp2. default c("blue", "gray95", "red"). colList named list named vectors specifying custom color information pass ComplexHeatmap::Heatmap(). list many elements annotation columns, element name correspond exactly name annotation column. colors vector elements named according levels factor column's annotation data annotation discrete, produced circlize::colorRamp2 annotation continuous. default, ColorBrewer color sets used. See parameter colorSets additional details. show.pb logical, whether warnings output profiling suppressed (including progress bar output). Default FALSE. parallel.sz integer identifying number processors use running calculations parallel GSVA ssGSEA algorithms. parallel.sz = 0, cores used. default 0. output character string specifying whether outputted plot "heatmap" "boxplot". default "heatmap". num.boot integer indicating number times bootstrap data. column_order vector character strings indicating order manually arrange heatmap columns. Default NULL, column order automatically determined via clustering.

title: TB gene signatures that require retraining. — .OriginalModel_Retraining
text: Maertzdorf_4 Maertzdorf_15 trained using random forest distinguish patients active TB healthy controls. Verhagen_10 also trained using random forest distinguish samples active TB either latent infection healthy controls. random forest model build using randomForest. Jacobsen_3 trained using linear discriminant analysis (LDA) distinguish samples active TB latent infection status. Sambarey_HIV_10 also trained using LDA distinguish samples active TB either latent infection, healthy control, disease (HIV). LDA model built using lda. Berry_OD_86 Berry_393 trained using K-nearest neighbors (KNN) model differentiate samples active TB latent infection status. KNN model built using knn. Suliman_RISK_4 Zak_RISK_16 trained using support vector machines (SVM) distinguish TB progressor non-progressors. input gene expression features Suliman_RISK_4 used paired ratio GAS6/CD1C, SEPTIN4/BLK, SEPTIN4/CD1C, GAS6/BLK. SVM model built using svm.

text: function used perform reference batch correction imputation testing data gene signatures require retraining model. used k-nearest neighbors impute expression values missing gene(s). imputation operation achieved using impute.knn. Since computational time imputation step can excessive large number missing genes. made constrains prevent overflow imputation operation. evaluation run geneMax*100% percent genes found corresponding gene signature input study. default geneMax = 0.8, evaluation run 80% genes missing matching input study reference data.

title: A function for reference batch correction and imputation. — ref_combat_impute
code: ref_combat_impute(   theObject_train,   useAssay,   gene_set,   input,   SigName,   adj,   geneMax = 0.8 )

title: A function for reference batch correction and imputation. — ref_combat_impute
text: theObject_train SummarizedExperiment object pre-stored data file: OriginalTrainingData. useAssay character string integer specifying assay input. Used test SummarizedExperiment object. Default 1, indicating first assay test SummarizedExperiment object. gene_set character vector includes gene symbols selected gene signature. input SummarizedExperiment object gene symbols assay row names. SigName Optional. character string indicates name gene_set. SigName used provide information gene signatures missing test data. adj small real number used combat solve genes 0 counts rare cases. required cases. geneMax real number 0 1. used detect maximum percent missing genes allowed evaluated signatures. See impute.knn details. default value 0.8.

title: Run TB gene signature profiling. — runTBsigProfiler
code: runTBsigProfiler(   input,   useAssay = NULL,   signatures = NULL,   algorithm = c("GSVA", "ssGSEA", "ASSIGN", "PLAGE", "Zscore", "singscore"),   combineSigAndAlgorithm = FALSE,   assignDir = NULL,   outputFormat = NULL,   parallel.sz = 0,   ASSIGNiter = 1e+05,   ASSIGNburnin = 50000,   ssgsea_norm = TRUE,   update_genes = TRUE )

title: Run TB gene signature profiling. — runTBsigProfiler
text: Profiling Z-Score, PLAGE, GSVA, ssGSEA algorithms conducted Bioconductor GSVA package. Profiling singscore algorithm conducted Bioconductor singscore package.

title: Run TB gene signature profiling. — runTBsigProfiler
text: input input data object class SummarizedExperiment, data.frame, matrix containing gene expression data. Required. useAssay character string specifying assay use signature profiling input SummarizedExperiment. Required input data class SummarizedExperiment. null, assay used "counts". default NULL. signatures list signatures run associated genes. list format TBsignatures, included TBSignatureProfiler package. signatures = NULL, default set signatures TBsignatures list used. details, run ?TBsignatures. <2 genes signature present sample, signature evaluated present resulting SE object. default NULL. algorithm vector algorithms run, character string one desired. default c("GSVA", "ssGSEA", "ASSIGN", "PLAGE", "Zscore", "singscore"). combineSigAndAlgorithm logical, TRUE, output row names form <algorithm>_<signature>. must set codeTRUE ouputFormat SummarizedExperiment length(algorithm) > 1. always FALSE one algorithm selected. FALSE, column named algorithm' lists algorithm used, column named 'pathway' lists signature profiled. NULL, one algorithm used, algorithm listed. default FALSE. assignDir character string naming directory save intermediate ASSIGN results algorithm specifies "ASSIGN". default NULL, case intermediate results saved. outputFormat character string specifying output data format. Possible values "SummarizedExperiment", "matrix", "data.frame". default return type input object. parallel.sz integer identifying number processors use running calculations parallel GSVA ssGSEA algorithms. parallel.sz = 0, cores used. default 0. ASSIGNiter integer indicating number iterations use MCMC ASSIGN algorithm. default 100,000. ASSIGNburnin integer indicating number burn-iterations use MCMC ASSIGN algorithm. iterations discarded computing posterior means model parameters. default 50,000. ssgsea_norm logical, passed GSVA::gsva(). parameter algorithm = "ssgsea",profiler runs SSGSEA method Barbie et al. (2009) normalizing scores absolute difference minimum maximum, described paper. ssgsea.norm = FALSE, last normalization step skipped. default TRUE. update_genes logical, denotes whether gene names signatures rownames input checked accuracy using HGNChelper::checkGeneSymbols(). mapping assumes genes humans keep unmapped genes original input gene name. Default TRUE.

title: Run TB gene signature profiling. — runTBsigProfiler
text: SummarizedExperiment object, data.frame, matrix signature profiling results. returned object format specified outputFormat. input SummarizedExperiment outputFormat = "SummarizedExperiment", output retain input information stored input colData. general, outputFormat = "SummarizedExperiment" columns colData include scores desired signature samples rows. input data.frame matrix, returned object signatures rows samples columns.

title: Run TB gene signature profiling. — runTBsigProfiler
text: Barbie, D.., Tamayo, P., Boehm, J.S., Kim, S.Y., Moody, S.E., Dunn, .F., Schinzel, .C., Sandy, P., Meylan, E., Scholl, C., et al. (2009). Systematic RNA interference reveals oncogenic KRAS-driven cancers require TBK1. Nature 462, 108-112. doi: 10.1038/nature08460. Foroutan, M. et al. (2018). Single sample scoring molecular phenotypes. BMC Bioinformatics, 19. doi: 10.1186/s12859-018-2435-4. Lee, E. et al. (2008). Inferring pathway activity toward precise disease classification. PLoS Comp Biol, 4(11):e1000217. doi: 10.1371/journal.pcbi.1000217 Shen, Y. et al. (2015). ASSIGN: context-specific genomic profiling multiple heterogeneous biological pathways. Bioinformatics, 31, 1745-1753. doi: 10.1093/bioinformatics/btv031. Subramanian, . et al. (2005). Gene set enrichment analysis: knowledge-based approach interpreting genome-wide expression profiles. PNAS, 102, 15545-15550. doi: 10.1073/pnas.0506580102. Tomfohr, J. et al. (2005). Pathway level analysis gene expression using singular value decomposition. BMC Bioinformatics, 6:225. doi: 10.1186/1471-2105-6-225

title: Run TB gene signature profiling. — runTBsigProfiler
code: ## Using a data.frame input/output  # Create some toy data to test Zak_RISK_16 signature, using 5 samples with low  # expression & five samples with high expression of the signatures genes. df_testdata <- as.data.frame(rbind(matrix(c(rnorm(80), rnorm(80) + 5), 16, 10,                              dimnames = list(TBsignatures$Zak_RISK_16,                              paste0("sample", seq_len(10)))),                       matrix(rnorm(1000), 100, 10,                              dimnames = list(paste0("gene", seq_len(100)),                              paste0("sample", seq_len(10)))))) res <- runTBsigProfiler(input = df_testdata,                         signatures = TBsignatures["Zak_RISK_16"],                         algorithm = c("GSVA", "ssGSEA"),                         combineSigAndAlgorithm = FALSE,                         parallel.sz = 1) #> Parameter update_genes is TRUE. Gene names will be updated. #> Running GSVA #> Running ssGSEA #> [1] "Calculating ranks..." #> [1] "Calculating absolute values from ranks..." #> [1] "Normalizing..." subset(res, res$pathway == "Zak_RISK_16") #>       pathway algorithm            sample1            sample2 #> 1 Zak_RISK_16      GSVA -0.534666666666668 -0.600632318501172 #> 2 Zak_RISK_16    ssGSEA  0.192383825351229  0.069521160142643 #>              sample3            sample4           sample5           sample6 #> 1 -0.736618705035972 -0.631807228915664 -0.52753894080997 0.496305732484076 #> 2 -0.166684761621847 0.0714328935283431 0.114638189730784 0.833315238378153 #>             sample7           sample8           sample9          sample10 #> 1 0.681304347826087 0.499178082191781 0.586710239651416 0.540224719101124 #> 2 0.833315238378153 0.832308838099057 0.833315238378153 0.833315238378153  ## Using a SummarizedExperiment input/output  # The TB_indian SummarizedExperiment data is included in the package. GSVA_res <- runTBsigProfiler(input = TB_indian,                              useAssay = "logcounts",                              signatures = TBsignatures["Zak_RISK_16"],                              algorithm = c("GSVA"),                              combineSigAndAlgorithm = FALSE,                              parallel.sz = 1) #> Parameter update_genes is TRUE. Gene names will be updated. #> Running GSVA #> Warning: 1 rows with constant values throughout the samples. #> Warning: Rows with constant values are discarded. GSVA_res$Zak_RISK_16 #>  [1]  0.6255317  0.6709665  0.4502341  0.7240338  0.5423896  0.5076658 #>  [7]  0.6268138 -0.3785315  0.5837650  0.3315927  0.5688302  0.5667150 #> [13]  0.6943893 -0.6998614  0.3244909  0.6782273 -0.6715210 -0.6758541 #> [19] -0.5738776 -0.7008174 -0.5409373 -0.5289045 -0.5812383 -0.6514118 #> [25] -0.6726977 -0.2904185 -0.5783098 -0.6327992 -0.6770838 -0.4487168 #> [31] -0.6444862 -0.1045107  0.6871138  0.1003890 -0.4337305 -0.5566492 #> [37]  0.3533240 -0.3596061  0.6574704 -0.3224089  0.2424746  0.2679882 #> [43]  0.1508951  0.3123478

title: Annotation information for published TB signatures. — sigAnnotData
text: disease variable indicates whether signature developed distinguish TB LTBI ("Disease"), TB combination diseases possibly LTBI ("OD"), TB Human Immunodeficiency Virus ("HIV"), TB pneumonia ("PNA"), identify risk progression TB ("RISK"), risk TB treatment failure ("FAIL"), classify treatment responses (.e., failures cures, "RES"). tissue type variable denotes whether signature developed using samples either whole blood/paxgene peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs). Due manipulation cells inherently required obtain PBMCs, many scientists prefer use whole blood samples analysis.

TRUE, boxplot notched. default FALSE. rotateLabels logical. TRUE, x-axis labels rotated. default FALSE. nrow integer giving number rows resulting array. ncol integer giving number columns resulting array. fill_colors vector color names used fill colors boxplot. NULL, colors supplied via RColorBrewer. default fill_colors = NULL.

code: library(SummarizedExperiment)  # Generate some artificial data that shows a difference in Zak_RISK_16 mat_testdata <- rbind(matrix(c(rnorm(80), rnorm(80) + 5), 16, 10,                              dimnames = list(TBsignatures$Zak_RISK_16,                                              paste0("sample", seq_len(10)))),                       matrix(rnorm(1000), 100, 10,                              dimnames = list(paste0("gene", seq_len(100)),                                              paste0("sample", seq_len(10)))))  # Create a SummarizedExperiment object that contains the data testdataSE <- SummarizedExperiment(assays = SimpleList(data = mat_testdata),                                    colData = DataFrame(sample =                                                          c(rep("down", 5),                                                            rep("up", 5))))  # Run profiler using GSVA and ssGSEA on Zak_RISK_16 signature res <- runTBsigProfiler(testdataSE, useAssay = "data",                         signatures = TBsignatures["Zak_RISK_16"],                         algorithm = c("GSVA", "ssGSEA"), parallel.sz = 1,                         combineSigAndAlgorithm = TRUE) #> Parameter update_genes is TRUE. Gene names will be updated. #> Running GSVA #> Running ssGSEA #> [1] "Calculating ranks..." #> [1] "Calculating absolute values from ranks..." #> [1] "Normalizing..." signatureBoxplot(res, signatureColNames = c("GSVA_Zak_RISK_16",                                             "ssGSEA_Zak_RISK_16"),                  annotationColName = "sample", name = "Zak_RISK_16 Signature") #> Warning: Use of `boxplotdfm$Group` is discouraged. #> ℹ Use `Group` instead. #> Warning: Use of `boxplotdfm$Group` is discouraged. #> ℹ Use `Group` instead. #> Warning: Use of `boxplotdfm$Score` is discouraged. #> ℹ Use `Score` instead. #> Warning: Use of `boxplotdfm$Group` is discouraged. #> ℹ Use `Group` instead. #> Warning: Use of `boxplotdfm$Score` is discouraged. #> ℹ Use `Score` instead.

See parameter colorSets additional details. colorSets vector names listing color sets order used creating heatmap. default, function use color sets order listed Usage annotation information. may replace default collection sets order want use , provide custom color sets colList parameter. choose_color vector color names interpolated heatmap gradient, colorRamp function produced circlize::colorRamp2. default c("blue", "gray95", "red"). column_order vector character strings indicating order manually arrange heatmap columns. Gene names will be updated. #> Running GSVA #> Running ssGSEA #> [1] "Calculating ranks..." #> [1] "Calculating absolute values from ranks..." #> [1] "Normalizing..."  # Plot a heatmap of signature genes and pathway predictions signatureGeneHeatmap(res, useAssay = "data",                      sigGenes = TBsignatures[["Zak_RISK_16"]],                      signatureColNames = c("GSVA_Zak_RISK_16",                                            "ssGSEA_Zak_RISK_16"),                      annotationColNames = c("sample"), showColumnNames = FALSE,                      name = "Zak_RISK_16")

title: Create a table of results for t-tests and bootstrapped AUCs for multiple scored signatures. — tableAUC
text: SE_scored SummarizedExperiment object genes row features signature scores colData. also column annotation data. Required. annotationColName character string giving column name colData contains annotation data. Required. signatureColNames vector column names colData contain signature score data. Required. num.boot integer. number times bootstrap data. default 100. pb.show logical whether show progress bar running code. default TRUE. output character string indicating table output format. Possible values DataTable data.frame. default DataTable.
